title: Bosses reveal the emails you should NEVER keep in your work inbox
text:
From online shopping orders to flirty messages, employers have revealed the emails you should never keep in your work inbox.

Some 300 bosses from across the UK responded to a survey conducted by CV-Library to reveal the types of emails that should never be sent or received on a company address.

It comes as 44 per cent of respondents admitted they had caught employees with 'unacceptable' messages.

Some 300 bosses from across the UK responded to a survey to reveal the types of emails that should never be sent or received on a company address. Stock image

Revealed: Workplace emails that could land you in trouble Inappropriate images (72.1%) Talking negatively about colleagues (56.4%) Job applications to other employers (48.5%) Flirty emails with colleagues (33.8%) Complaining about your job (31.9%) Talking negatively about your boss (25.5%) Online shopping orders (11.3%) Personal emails to friends and family (7.8%)

Unsurprisingly, 'inappropriate images' topped the list, with 72 per cent of employers deeming them inappropriate.

They were followed by 'talking negatively about colleagues' (57 per cent), job applications to outside employers (49 per cent) and flirty emails with colleagues (34 per cent).

Among the less obvious transgressions were 'online shopping orders' (11 per cent) and personal emails to friends and family (8 per cent).

Lee Biggins, founder and CEO of CV-Library, urged workers to think twice before sending, receiving or forwarding emails from a work address.

Unsurprisingly, 'inappropriate images' topped the list, with 72 per cent of employers deeming them inappropriate. However online shopping also made an appearance. Stock image

He said: 'You'd have to be pretty brave to let any of these emails sit in your work inbox. In an increasingly digitalised world, we can't afford to become complacent about what we're sending over email.

'Professional conduct in the workplace is just as important online as it is offline.

'Whether you forward the email to a colleague or your manager monitors your inbox, these have a habit of coming to light and often with serious consequences.

'So, ditch the dodgy emails and remember, what happens in your inbox doesn't always stay in your inbox.'
